Dear mr harsh modi... First of all, your knowledge about smartphones seems to be pretty outdated... The sealed battery doesn't effect anything, heating problem is because of the metal back, it feels more warmer than a glass or plastic back, if you go and check it with a heat gun you will find the difference... All the phones weather it be the S8 too, they heat up, it depends on your usage...
 
Secondly, li-ion batteries are meant to be charged again and again, it won't differ if we even even charge it 100 times a day, what would be wrong is to drain it till 0% and then charge, this reduces the battery's capacity to hold charge, li-ion battery's charge should be maintained between 20% to 90%....
 
P.s if you don't have the proper knowledge don't say..

Strange to heat your reviews.. I m a regular user of One plus.. I never faced such issue in my life ever. 
For your heating problem I would like to inform your that the battery is non removable and usually phones whose battery cannot be removed will get heat. That's a common thing in those. Even iPhone gets heated.
 
For your automatically calling problem I would ask you to turn on pocket mode and close the unnecessary gestures. 
The calling issue wont ever trouble you anymore. 
For your battery draining. done charge the phone unless its less than 15-20%.  
Usually I've seen may people will play game over the cellphone and keep the phone for charging every now & then, this practice hampers the battery life and health.
 
Still an of the issue continues please show it to service station and ask them to hard reset the phone completely and then once its done with reset enable the developer option and in that you can reduce the battery unnecessary consumption.
 
Hope above advise me help you but please don't say its worst phone.

The 30 u say is the shutter speed, that has been set for 30 seconds. So, your phone is gonna capture for 30 seconds. That's why the "capturing" screen stays on and on for all that while (30 seconds to be precise).  
Having said that, the slow shutter speed can help you shoot some amazing shots like light trails and blurred flowing water.. 
Similarly, you can decrease the shutter speed too (upto 1/8000 I think), which can help you snap fast moving objects, like the rotating fan for example. But one issue is, lowering the shutter speed, lowers the light entering the lens, thus the images would turn out to be dark. So, you'll have to crank up the ISO accordingly (which would bring in lot of noise unfortunately).
 
Read about the exposure triangle in the internet. There's a lot of stuff the OnePlus 3 can do!

Good: 
* fast charging 
* fast cpu 
* fast camera  
* images taken on a bright day 
* basically unlimited amount of RAM 
* looks good and is well built 
* pixel density on screen (only HD, but its enough)
 
Meh:  
* fingerprint sensor (its fast, but not completely reliable)
 
Bad:  
* screen is greenish when looked at angle 
* power button can get too easily pushed (read: unintentionally pushed in pocket)
 
Ugly:  
* sound quality (hands-down the worst sound on any phone I've ever had) 
* sound on videos (sometimes there is almost no sound at all. And yes, I don't mute the sound by holding my finger on mic or speaker) 
* ambient light sensor (just turn it off, it doesn't work)
 
So, its a phone. Its not a flagship killer or something that we will remember in 5years. Though I don't regret buying it.

The phone it self is very good. Strong build. Good camera. Fast and responsive. 
 
The size is just good, slightly smaller would have been better for me to be honest.
 
However, i don't think it is the value for money phone everyone keeps talking about. You will end up paying similar to what you pay for an S7 if not more. That is because it only comes with a charger and that's it. No headphones, nothing... just a plug and a cable for the weird new form of USB that it is equipped with. So it won't really be compatible with any of the chargers you own, you have to buy more if you want to have one for the home and another for the office, and then for the car as well. The standard USB cable does not work...
 
Moreover because of this new USB form, you don't have the luxury of directly plugging a USB stick for extra memory or memory backup.AND you don't have a memory card slot. So when i bought i'd compensate for the lack of expandable memory with an external memory stick for backup but NO. won't work. You're stuck in the new USB system... 
 
So apart from the new USB, all else is good... so far...

I really like the camera ^^

Coming from an OPO for a 27mth period I am quite happy with the improvements of the 3. I am fine w a 1080p AMOLED screen and I find overall I have the brightness quite low which aids in battery life. Battery life to date is decent, dash charging excellent. I was strongly considering a Nexus 6p 64gb just for the slightly larger screen but every phone has issues, whether it be the muffled voice or rotation as example not working on the 6p I opted for the OPO3 not because it does not have faults but rather it just has better hardware.
 
A Snap 820 is better than a 810 and a 530 better than 430 and Dash charging better than fast charging and handling the OPO3 easier than 6p. However the 6p screen is nicer but for my older eyes 1080p is fine, heck my 70" TV is 1080p so let's just step back and think about that before we go off on QHD for 5.5-6" phones. Having 6gb or ram hopefully in future will be a benefit and all I want out of this phone is the same reliability my  OPO gave me for 27-30 mths before I sell it to try something new out. All else aside I would like to see an HTC 10 like quality DAC and possibly expandable storage, for me the new camera is a huge improvement. After having this phone for about a month now, I have to say IÂm overall really impressed for a $400 device. 
 
From a look and feel perspective, the OP3 ticks all the right boxes. Great, premiumÂif somewhat genericÂdesign aesthetic. Beautiful screen (1080p is perfectly serviceable for anything but VR, and it helps save on battery life). Logical placement of all the controls, buttons and (user-assignable) capacitive keys. And dat notification slider, thoÂwonderful, practical design. 
 
Under the hood IÂm really fairly pleased as well. This phone is as fast and stable (and 100% less explodey) as the Note 7 it replacedÂa phone that costs OVER DOUBLE the OP3Âs asking price. IÂve had only one app crash in a month and even that seems like an app issue, rather than the phoneÂs core hardware/software. 
 
The camera will be an issue for some people as it falls squarely into the ÂfineÂ range. ItÂs by no means bad, but nor is it class leading in any way. The softwareÂs good and it consistently produces pretty good shots in a variety of conditions. But that 200-series Sony sensor just canÂt compete against current, more expensive, flagship cameras. Still, fine is good enough for me in the camera department. 
 
Heard the phoneÂs launch firmware had some memory management and battery life problems but I havenÂt experienced either in day-to-day use and I can usually squeeze a (acceptable, if a bit unimpressive) full day of frequent but untaxing use out of the device. Fast (or Dash, as itÂs branded here) charging does work really well and helps make up for the somewhat ÂfineÂ battery life. Word of warning, thoughÂOnePlusÂ Dash charging ONLY works with their proprietary Dash Charging cables AND proprietary Dash Charging wall adapter. Not a big deal for me but YMMV. 
 
On the software and OS side, itÂs more of the sameÂnot a bad thing in this case. The Oxygen OS skin is light and doesnÂt seem to be slowing anything down (which, honestly, is all I really require of an Android skin) and actually manages to add in some useful/fun features. Being able to change your notification LED color is nice, if somewhat useless. Screen-off pattern commands are limited but work well (draw a V on the screen to turn the flashlight on or off, right arrow to skip to the next song, etc). But the real standout features are the ability to customize your capacitive keys to your liking. Want to launch you camera with a double-tap of the Home key? Sure. Want long-press Back to open up your last used app? No problem. Want to swap the Back and Recent buttons to make it feel more Samsung? You got it. I donÂt know why this simple customization feature isnÂt on all phones. 
 
Not everything about the OS was great though, and I did find the lack of Home/Lock screen and app drawer customization a little annoying. Still, it was nothing Nova Launcher couldnÂt fix and the performance hasnÂt taken any kind of hit from the change. 
 
So a month in, and IÂm really pretty pleased with the OP3. Pleased enough, in fact, that I am seriously considering sticking with OnePlus for the OP4 next year. But there are a couple things that I would like to see before I give OnePlus my money next year. 
 
1) Waterproofing. I know this is a feature some people donÂt care about but for me it is the single biggest feature I would like to see added for the OP4. And, conversely, if there is one thing that might entice me back to Samsung or Sony, itÂs a LACK of waterproofing in the OP4. A lot of people live in rainy places and this is a big deal where I live. I would have GLADLY paid an extra $50 for a ip68 model of the OP3.
 
2) Better battery life. The OP3Âs battery life is okay. But it could be a lot better. Almost certainly, market pressureÂs gonna make OnePlus but a 2k screen in the OP4 and I hope they make sure the battery life can keep up to that change (even if they have to thicken the device a little bit to add a bigger cell). 
 
Do these 2 things, OnePlus, and you have my money with the OP4.

YeahÂthatÂs absolutely not normal. I would upgrade to the newest firmware. If that doesnÂt fix the problem, try a full restore of the device (might be some kind of persistent memory leak issue?)
 
If that doesnÂt fix it, contact OnePlus and have them replace it. It may just be a defective unit. 
 
I usually get a full day and evening of heavy but non-intensive use (basic web browsing, lowish screen brightness mostly) without much problem. Usually starts getting into single digits around 2000 or 2100 at night.

They are a couple of options depending on what you want. If you go into settings>battery and at the top right there should be a battery symbol. If you tap that, one option is to show the percentage, but no other symbol. If you want the percentage in the battery symbol it's a bit more complicated. Pull down the quick settings and hold down on the settings cog in the top right for about 5-10 seconds. When you let go a new option for system UI tuner should be at the bottom of your settings menu. In this menu is an option to show the percentage in the symbol.

I've been using my OnePlus3 for more than a month and it's really a great mobile & I'm loving this mobile. 
1. Camera quality is moderate (I know it before purchasing,I dont use camera much) 
2. Battery is really awesome. (It charges very fast with the dash charging and I've been charging only once in a day. I'm a big surfer who uses Internet,fb,Whatsapp for the whole day) 
3. Performance is also great and I've not seen any apps getting hanged. 
4. I got the mobile with 3.2.2 Oxygen OS, I haven't upgraded to 3.24 since I've read reviews about heating issues after updating to 3.2.4.But I waited for 3.2.6 and updated and No heating/battery draining problems at all. 
5. OnePlus3 team is doing a very good job on fixing the Issues with their updates. 
 
Overall, I love this mobile and I'll refer to anyone on this Earth. 
 
Just a small tip for those who want to buy this mobile, who are hesitating due to the comments/review on battery issues/heating problems.
 
Handling a mobile for the first 2-3 days is very much considered.  
1. Don't use your mobile while charging (atleast for first three days) 
2. After charging for 100%, let it drain upto atleast 10% before charging again 
3. Atleast for 2-3 days dont play High end games till the battery gets used to your routine usage 
4. Don't charge your mobile with other chargers 
5. Avoid charging the mobile in PC/Laptops

Camera - Poor. Software is lacking so much 
Storage - 54.x+ left, enough and with 250GB google drive + photos, I don't miss SDCard 
Processor/Graphics = The processor is the FASTEST thing I've ever seen, never thought a phone could perform so well, lagless and simply FAST, very FAST. 
Screen quality - Could be better, much better.
 
This phone outperforms EVERY phone out there so far, and I've reviewed MANY, from Moto to Galaxy to iCrap. Debatable.  A lot of Android relies on the memory management technique called garbage collection-- reasonably efficient on the CPU, but kinda inefficient for memory use.  More memory generally helps garbage-collection run better.    So, Android can chew up more RAM than you might otherwise expect.  That said, you probably don't need 6 gigs today. 
(this is neglecting OxygenOS's current, questionable background-process management.)
 
For my part, I see it as future-proofing.  I plan to keep this phone for a couplethree years and, while we know the CPU's and GPU's will get faster, its memory shouldn't be a problem.

Dear Mandy, what your talking about is call waiting =means when you have taken on a call and somebody else is trying to reach you while your still have conversation with the other person, you'll hear 2 beep sounds on your ear piece, that basically indicating that there's another person trying to reach you at the same time, you have the option to take the call by putting the first person you were speaking to on hold and take the new call, if you ignore the call basically mean's you don't want to take their call and your busy (Your telephone operator doesn't mention that your talking to somebody else, the other caller just gets a message saying the current caller can't take your call, which isn't as same as your talking to somebody.) 
 
The manual option that your operators customer service personnel had mentioned about is about turning off the the call waiting option. Go through some youtube video's about call waiting options and turn off call waiting.

Moreover a continuous charge might damage your battery and soon be worn out if fast charge continues upto 100%

I've had the OnePlus 3 for over a month now and I am enjoying the phone quite a bit.
 
I do have a few issues with the phone. One being the fact that when my WiFi starts to slow down, the phone completely disconnects from the network and interrupts my app use. Specifically the games I play which require constant connections to the game. This could be a rare problem, I haven't looked into it so it may be only my problem. Another issue some people may have is the camera bulge. Compared to the previous OnePlus devices, the camera was aligned with the phone casing and was not an issue. It is now an issue. I haven't had a problem with it because I purchased a case along with the phone, but for people who don't have a case, it may cause problems.
 
When I bought the phone, I had no idea the home button was touch. It only took me a few days to get used to. I love the fingerprint scanner. It is super reliable and fast. The only issue with the scanner is that when your phone is plugged in(charging), the finger scanner gets buggy and wont read correctly. Odd issue, but I dealt with it. 
 
The last important problem is not having an SD slot. I know it's a petty thing to have an issue with, but I do like the extra space, but unfortunately with this phone, you don't have that luxury.
 
The smartphone does have many qualities that I'd like to point out. The speed is impeccable. With the unique(or new advancement) 6 GB of RAM, the phone is able to function at super fast speeds. The Snapdragon 820 cards keep the phone running multiple apps simultaneously without slowing down.
 
What I really love about the phone, is that the phone looks very slim and it somehow looks small, but don't be alarmed, the phone is just slightly smaller than the Samsung Notes and the screen size is perfect. The resolution of the screen is great and you are able to run up to 2160 at 30 frames per second. The contrast is exactly what anyone looks for as well. You are able to adjust the warmth and coolness of the screen which really helps with preference and battery life. The screen brightness in general is very bright, so in the sun, if turned to the max setting, makes for a very visible screen. The size of the screen to the size of the phone is perfect. There is barely any space left between the end of the phone to the screen size. It looks very clean in this element. The phone in general looks extremely elegant.
 
The cameras on the phone are incredible. The main camera(outfacing) is a stunning 16 megapixels and offers the clearest of photos for smartphones out there in 2016. If you're a big junkie on cameras on phones and love the way iPhones can snap pictures super fast with incredible shutter speeds, then this is your phone. The camera is way better and offers slow motion videos alike the new iPhones. It's important to know that android cameras are often(because of software) slower and the shutter speeds are slower as the phone gets older and pictures can get difficult to take and you have to hold the phone super still for photos to be clear. But the OnePlus 3 does not have that problem. With the increased speed of the phone, software and hardware can run in perfect symmetry making for a super smooth and comfortable use in any situation. The front facing camera(selfies!) is 8 mega pixels. It's alike any new iPhone. Very clear photos and a bunch of options for choice of camera use. The flash is somewhat bright. It's not super powerful, but it's enough if your in a dark close space and need a bit of light.
 
Although the battery size is smaller than other phones its "size", the battery lasts quite a long time considering the size is almost 600 mAh on average lower than other phones this big. The dash charge works great. It charges almost 50% in 20 minutes.
 
The speakers on the phone are a little low quality. It's sound quality is clear, but it lacks the bass and treble sound limits. The microphone is clear. I've heard someone call me from my phone before just to test it out and it's very clear when in Skype and on regular calls.
 
All in all, this phone is a great phone. It runs incredibly fast which is a main feature, being the performance, and is what pretty much everyone looking for a phone is after. It's look is super clean and it's quite a beautiful phone. The price is what got me on this phone. It goes for $520 USD. I compared this phone very closely to the Samsung S7 Edge. In terms of performance and all the qualities of a phone, it's very similar, aside from the Samsung being the "Edge". The price difference is vast and for the price of the OnePlus 3, you cannot get anything better. It truly is an incredible phone and I don't regret trying out this phone.

The overheating issue in OnePlus 2 you speak of was due to Snapdragon 810. 
Snapdragon 810 had severe overheating issues, all Snapdragon 810 devices suffered from overheating issues, the one and only phone where Snapdragon 810 overheating issues were tamed was Lumia 950XL because it utilized a powder based cooling system which is usually used in fanless laptops but that's a totally different story, no other phone manufacturers use such a cooling system. 
However OnePlus 3 uses Snapdragon 820 which isn't as prone to overheating issues like 810, so don't worry OnePlus 3 doesn't overheat too much like OnePlus 2, however if you compare the temperature with Exynos 8890 Octa and Kirin 955 powered devices then you ought to be dissapointed because Snapdragon 820 still heats up more than Exynos 8890 Octa and Kirin 955, but the temperatures aren't outrageous as Snapdragon 810.

The RAM management issue isn't as severe as been spoken of. 
Even without rooting and RAM fix the phone is quite good, of course you won't be able to utilize the full 6GB capacity of RAM but even without fix OnePlus 3 is able to utilize 4GB RAM easily. So overall performance won't be a issue however after rooting and putting the fix it works little faster but in real world scenario you won't see much difference.

Okay let's see.... 
Let's proceed in order. 
This phone is factory unlocked, so yeah you can grab any plan with this phone. 
Are you able to pay 500$ (or more)? If no, it is not for you. 
Are you seeking for a big screen phone? If no, it is not for you. 
Are you seeking for an amazing tech support? If yes, it is not for you. 
This phone has great specs, with its S820, FHD display, big battery and camera. 
The UI is close to stock, so pretty much bloatware-free. 
The 6 GB of RAM are LPDDR4, which is great, but mostly useless. 
This phone is horrible for VR beacause of its screen. 
This phone has an AMOLED display, which helps saving the battery by turning off pixels that shows the black color. 
This phone has 64 GB of storage NOT EXPANDABLE, so if you need more, better find a phone with an SD card slot or an USB-OTG-Ready Mass storage device, but if you aren't making a 4K movie, you should be okay. 
Supports LTE-A (category 9) 
It has its issues, but it seems OnePlus is working on it. 
You should buy it if you want a less expensive phone that gives high-end power, but you should not if you are seeking for fast updates, QHD, VR, Dual Sim, great support or options other manufacturers offers.
 
You could also check for the Xiaomi Mi 5, it is about the same.

I had one, sold it within a week. Unwieldly large body, battery weakness, and only used as a phone. Sound quality poor and muffled, I had difficulty understanding callers voices. Bought a UMI Super instead, still a bit unwieldly and large, but great 4000mAh battery, 32GB ROM and 4GB RAM, Screen colours can be adjusted for richness and therefore comes close to the OP3 amoled vibrancy and.... half the price of the OP3. I can find little or no difference to speed between the UMI at 4GB Ram and the OP3 6GB Ram. Both phones are steel bodied and gorilla glass. The difference in price is probably aided by the UMI having the MTK P10 processor, which incidentally is smooth and without lag, and the OP3 having the latest Snapdragon 820 processor, but basically the UMI Super 5.5 is a good value and efficient device and a very, very good price: See 'Aliexpress' for prices, some are available with free shipping.

I have read lots of comments before I decided to buy this phone. Most comments are "how bad this phone is". At that moment I had S7 edge in my pocket. Finally I've decided to buy OP3...and surprise. It's SUCH A GREAT PHONE at the most decent price ever. I've become a FAN instant of OnePlus. Every cent was spent with brain when they made this phone. It is true that battery is drained faster, but you can charge it faster then it drains. And btw, battery is drained if you play like a maniac, but this is not a video console, its a phone. It's not a TV or notebook, it's a phone. Signal is impressive, sound is great on earpiece. It's ok on speaker and colors are almost near the S7 Edge. IT is true that S7 edge 2k display is a little "nice" when you put both phones together, but for that it ain't worth the money on S7 edge. Camera quality is almost near S7 Edge..but it seems noone can beat the samsung's cameras. For daily basis pics its more then ok. Overall is a GREAT PHONE.

It really depends on your preferences.  The screen looks fine to my eyes so far (after about 2 full days with the phone).  It may not be the most accurate colours, so if you need to do professional photo touch-ups or graphic design work on your phone, it's probably not a great choice, but I think for many (most?) people, it will look fine or even quite good.  
 
The RAM management I guess is an issue.  Again it depends what and how many apps you want to have open at once.  I've seen it re-load Feedly on me a few times, but that could be an application quirk as that's the only one I've really noticed it on so far.  I routinely have one or more chat apps (Textra (SMS), BBM, WhatsApp, Slack), Fenix (for Twitter), Feedly, Chrome, Gmail app, 9 (another email app I use for work emails) or some subset of those open pretty much all the time.  I think it's a bigger issue if you want to load some of the larger games and still be able to swap out to other apps to do things and swap back without reloading.
 
The other thing to consider is that there is an OTA update coming (no idea when) that will address both of these issues you have called out. 
 
In the end, it's up to you and your preferences/priorities, but to me, the phone is pretty hard to beat for value.

Both versions contain the same 2G support:   
GSM 850 / 900 / 1800 / 1900 - SIM 1 & SIM 2
 
For 3G HSPA, they differ: 
HSDPA 850 / 900 / 1700(AWS) / 1900 / 2100 - North America 
HSDPA 850 / 900 / 1900 / 2100 - Global model
 
And also for 4G: 
LTE band 1(2100), 2(1900), 4(1700/2100), 5(850), 7(2600), 8(900), 12(700), 17(700) - North America 
LTE band 1(2100), 3(1800), 5(850), 7(2600), 8(900), 20(800), 38(2600), 40(2300), 41(2500) - Global model
 
Will the Global version (assuming that's what's served up in the UK) work in Canada?  Well, it somewhat depends what carrier's network you are on.
 
If you are on Rogers/Fido/Chatr (maybe others) that operate on the Rogers network, you will at least get phone, text, and very slow (EDGE) data via the 2G (GSM) network.  Bell and Telus and their brands (Virgin, Public Mobile, Koodo, probably others) do NOT operate a 2G network at all, so that option is out.
 
I am not very familiar with what frequencies Rogers uses for 3G, so I'm not sure.  Telus and Bell use 850 and 1900 MHz, so I believe either version of the phone will get you 3G service, so voice, texting, and medium-speed data (HSPA/HSPA+).  
 
When it comes to 4G LTE Data is where you will run into trouble.  All of the big Canadian networks primarily run on band 4, which is NOT in the global version.  Band 7 is, and it is also used in at least some areas on the major carriers too, so you may get intermittent LTE based on where you are.  But missing band 4 really means your LTE support is not good in Canada.
 
For Wind....  I think you HAVE to have the North American version, as they operate on the 1700/2100 frequencies (aka AWS) for both 3G and 4G, and the global version does not support that at all.  I think you will get zero service on Wind on the global version.
 
On the North American version, you will be fine on every Canadian carrier today, Wind included.
 
EDIT:  forgot to mention the OnePlus site doesn't show you the global version info because you're browsing from within Canada.  :)  (or the US)  It only shows you the specs for your region.

I received the phone yesterday from Amazon. Took just 3 days to reach me and I am amazed by the quick delivery. Now guys all about the long awaited one plus3. Oled full HD display is fantastic with very rich colors. I had a Lenovo vibe z2 pro which had a quad HD display but one plus 3 full HD display is no less. The difference is quite negligible. The build materials are top notch and looks like an amalgamation of HTC one and iPhone 6s. Build quality feels premium and the slight curvature feels good at the edges. Camera does protrude a bit. But a case can cover it up although I prefer it without a case as it will hide it's premium built aluminum. Sound is far better than my previous handsets I used so doesn't trouble me as I have found for some people regarding audio output. Now the best part the processor and ram. I still don't understand all the fuss regarding 6gb ram but to be honest the phone feels so fast I didn't even notice how much memory it uses. 4gb or 6gb it doesn't matter bcoz for this price range I would not even if one plus 3 had a gimmick about 6gb. In short it's superfast. Camera is also awesome. Fingerprint scanner was the fastest I have ever seen. Battery was something I worried about but to my surprise it's got a lot of punch than its capacity 3000mah dictates. I have been using with full display and had all updates from WiFi and it lasted almost one day. So guys no need to think twice just go for it as its way more value for money than a 55000 s7 or HTC 10.

Got OP3 yesterday with a perfect amazon delivery. Have used Samsung Galaxy S2 and then HTC 820 S.  Both these previous phones were really good. But OP3  seems to be better than both. Looks and feel -unbelievably beautiful and a pride to hold.  Probably this is the design  which  a future phone should target - it has got a royal appearance.  5.5 screen is optimum as was evident from my HTC.  Screen clearity is perfect, colours appear natural, dark mode awsome. Speaker and call volume loud. Have not checked headphone sound.  FP sensor lightning fast. My first requirement was a dual sim device, and actually wanted expandable memory. But 64 gb seems OK as in my previous HTC 80gb---30 gb was always free.  Apps open and close very very fast. Camera shot on HD setting  in a cloudy sky was so clear that on zooming it appeared to be an optical zoom which my Canon camera has.   To me,  this phone appears future proof for atleast another year,  in terms of design and speed.  I had thought of Iphone 6S plus- but single sim, exorbitant and irrational price, and not so attractive design [ a few new handsets owned by my friends appear to be old used handsets]--I postponed the idea.   Just like me, I would recommend this phone today instead of an IPhone  and wait for future IPhones . . . to be dual sim, attractive and pocket friendly.

folks, don't just go by the specs to draw conclusions. 
I have been using this phone for the past three days and here are my observations -  
 - buttery smooth 
 - battery backup is decent - 4hr 30 mins of SOT and it will last you a full day - usage is mainly voice calls, internet browsing over wifi and light media consumption on the youtube and spotify app. Standby time is also good. You lose 3-4 percent for 8hrs of standby. 
 - RAM usage with 10 apps open was around 47%. I did not notice any memory leakage issue.  
 - No noticeable software bugs - update your phone to the 3.1.2 update as soon as you set it up.
 
the only con i can think of is the metal build is too damn slippery. It is mandatory to have a good case.

1. Bezels
 
The perfect sweet spot, not too thin, not too thick (sony), not too weird or fancy (moto x, z)
 
2. Fingerprint reader
 
The best in the business. Very fast, checked alongside Nexus 6P, iPhone 5s, Mi Note3. Faster than pressing that power button!
 
3. Metallic back n body
 
This looks beautiful! No, really! No ugliness anywhere, the aluminum feels very premium.
 
4. Screen
 
Hmm, it's good, I don't think anyone would ever notice anything bad about this screen, i don't know, I'm a Moto X user since 2.5 years and have been seeing supersaturated black n color on AMOLED all this while. This screen is not that saturated, feels a little more real. 
No complains about the screen resolution. Cmon guys, none of us need 2k 4k displays yet.
 
5. Battery
 
First charge lasted almost two days, with no extra apps installed, without wifi, and half the time on Airtel LTE. Must be good for one full day's usage.
 
6. Charging
 
Daaaayyymmm!!! 0-100 in an hour ! 2% per minute almost! And that charger looks and feels like a transformer!
 
7. USB Type C
 
I don't know what to do with this yet.
 
8. Camera
 
Initial pics turned out to be really good, front camera is crisp. I'm more of a post processing and editing guy. But these pics look like a damn good place to start. My Moto X first gen camera was very sufficient for my needs, hope that gives you some perspective any my opinion.
 
9. Oxygen OS
 
OK so I was hitting the wrong button for back since the time I started using the phone, got fed up and started looking for the option to make the buttons on screen. But to my absolute surprise, I found the option to flip the back button to the other side! Waaaaaat! I've never before got wherever I have wanted this precisely! And then there are the long tap and double tap for each button, that you can assign different functions to. 
Many little settings that are useful.
 
10. Hardware n specs
 
It never hangs. I'm sure it won't. I'm not much of a gamer, I have a laptop for that. This one is more than up to date hardware wise.
 
Overall, well I am more of an aesthetics guy. I was thinking of getting the Galaxy S7. No other Android phone looked or felt better than that currently. But didn't want to put in half a lakh oh a phone. And I wasn't actually keen on the One Plus 3, I didnt follow any updates or check for leaked design pics. Then I found the MKBHD review video ( ... ) and immediately knew then was the phone I wanted! Incidentally it was the same day it released on Amazon (I didn't know that) and I ordered it within the next few minutes!
 
No regrets! Never Settle!

Hi James.  This is a great question, and one I faced myself!  After researching several phone options (Moto X Play, Honor 5X, Moto G4 Plus, Zenfone 2/3, others), I had finally settled and was just about ready to order an Xperia Z3+.  Things I liked about it included: better physical size for me (I have small hands, to 5.2" is better for me than 5.5"), waterproof (great for rainy environment I live in), good overall specs for memory/storage/performance, good battery life, etc.  Oh and the price, and overall value.
 
The main drawback was many reports of overheating due to the Snapdragon 810.  Some say it's only when recording 4K video or gaming, some say it's even taking more than a few regular photos at a time, or doing other less intense tasks than gaming and video but as a power user juggling lots of apps and such.  I would fall into that latter category.  Also, some people said the Marshmallow update solved the overheating, others said it didn't.  It was hard to get a real feel for it.
 
I was about to order it on the 12th or 13th, but decided to wait for the OnePlus 3 announcement just to see how it would compare, and I was pretty blown away and ordered one just after the orders went live.  It's a bit bigger than I'd like, and not waterproof, but it has so many pluses including:  AMOLED screen (I'm a fan over IPS), double the RAM and storage (I'm okay with no SD with 64GB!), finger print reader (z3+ has none), and the 820 which is a lot better than the 810 in the Z3+. Also the metal body I think will be more durable than the glass-backed Z3+, which I was a bit worried about shattering as well.  
 
I'm still not 100% sure I made the right choice but I'm excited to get my OP3 late next week.  Honestly I don't think you can go too wrong with either.  What are your priorities when selecting a phone?  If only price, the Z3+ is cheaper.  If smaller form factor then Z3+.  If large screen then OP3.  If preformance then OP3.  Convenience of the fingerprint reader will be nice too.  It's really up to you!

Your RAM is responsable for the amount of background and foreground processes  your phone can handle. For example in multitasking, but also parallel intensive processes in certain apps or games.  
Your CPU is responsible processing speed, ergo how fast your phone can handle those processes. 
Do you see the difference? Speed and amount?
